title: As Tesla Protests Spread, Elon Musk Gets Ready to Enter the Restaurant Business
description: Two years ago, the Tesla leader and DOGE chief began to build a diner and drive-in theater in Los Angeles. Then he became a political lightning rod.
author: Pete Wells
excerpt: Two years ago, the Tesla leader and DOGE chief began to build a diner and drive-in theater in Los Angeles. Then he became a political lightning rod.

html:
You have a preview view of this article while we are checking your access. When we have confirmed access, the full article content will load.

Two years ago, the Tesla leader and DOGE chief began to build a diner and drive-in theater in Los Angeles. Then he became a political lightning rod.

Tesla is building a diner in Los Angeles that Elon Musk has described as “Grease meets Jetsons with Supercharging.”Credit...Jessica Pons for The New York Times

  • Published March 21, 2025Updated March 22, 2025, 4:45 p.m. ET

A retro-futuristic diner is rising on Santa Monica Boulevard in Los Angeles. Curved, silvery and flanked by two outdoor film screens, it looks as if a flying saucer had sailed out of a 1950s drive-in movie and come to rest in the parking lot.

An opening date has not been announced, but Tesla’s all-night diner, theater and charging station is clearly on its way. Which means that the company’s leader, Elon Musk, is about to enter the hospitality business.

In 2023, when Mr. Musk posted on X that Tesla would build a diner in the city, he described it as “Grease meets Jetsons with Supercharging.” As he has often done, he put his finger on a major piece of culture ripe for reinvention — in this case, gas-station dining in the age of electric cars, which need longer to recharge than it takes to top off a tank — and put a visionary, gee-whiz spin on it.

All of which have made Tesla’s foray into restaurants a far more loaded prospect than it seemed a short time ago.
